content.value: In a mesmerizing 56 seconds of the semifinals at the 2024 World Crokinole Championship, Connor Reinman and Jason Slater simultaneously secured perfect rounds.

value.figcaption: Double perfect round. Watch on YouTube.

content.value: Technically speaking, they each flicked a 3.2cm disc, 30cm across a board, into a 3.5cm hole (just 9% wider than the disc itself), eight times in a row. In game terms, they sank eight open 20s a piece. A rare gem of Crokinole perfection on display when the stakes couldn’t be higher.

How did we get here? How rare is a perfect round? Is Reinman vs. Slater the modern day Magic vs. Bird? Was this one of those obscure new Olympic events? You may even be wondering, wtf is Cronikole? If you find yourself sitting with any of these questions, then you’ve come to the right place.
This is a story about Crokinole. I am Russell Samora. And you are reading this now. Read on for answers to all these questions, and much more.

If you are from the southern region of the Canadian Province of Ontario, you may already be well-versed in Crokinole. But for the uninitiated, Crokinole is like a mashup of Shuffleboard and Curling, played on a tabletop board. It’s been around since the 19th century, but has seen a steady rise in global popularity in recent years.
(maybe make following scrollyteling/visual)

A super quick overview of the game: Players take turns flicking discs toward the center, aiming to score high while knocking opponent discs into lower zones or off the board. A shot must hit an opponent’s disc if one is present; otherwise, it must land in the inner circle (or score a 20 in the center hole). The round winner is whoever has the most points, and games consist of multiple rounds. Watch this video for a more thorough rules explanation.

Connor Reinman, the back-to-back world champion, and Justin Slater, the perennial powerhouse, are arguably the greatest players on the Crokinole world stage right now.
But how good are they? Let’s start by looking at their open 20 skills, an indispensable skill among the elite.
(chart- table of open 20% in the 2023-2024 season)
Both Reinman and Slater are among the best competitive players at open 20s, making 65% and 75% respectively. On average, a top competitive player makes around 55% of their open 20s.

For these players, making 8 straight open 20s in live-game action should happen only about 1 in every 120 rounds. That is like an NBA player making 20 straight free throws during the season. Not impossible, but definitely not common either.

But it's just flicking a little disc across a small table, how hard can it be, right? Let’s contextualize their skill by comparing it to some “ordinary” folks. Here is some data from my local club of non-competitive players. Our experience ranges from a handful to hundreds of games.
(chart- viz showing results of different levels of people and their success rate)

And keep in mind this is in-game play, where a player’s open 20 rhythm is broken up by various other types of shots. In a vacuum, they can do some pretty impressive things. Take Shawn Hagarty for example, who recently set an unofficial world record of 64 straight open 20s.

content.value: So back to our double perfect round. Time for some light statistics. The odds of the best players hitting 8 in a row is roughly 1 in 25, or just 4% chance. Two players both doing it at the same time? 1 in 3,551, or 0.028% of the time. For “average” pros that drops to X.
But that is in a theoretical scenario. In actual gameplay, an opponent’s play is equally important to even having the opportunity to make 8 straight, regardless of how much a player is feeling it.
(chart- when people tend to miss - first to miss data)

But perfect rounds depend a lot on your opponent’s play. Something about ricochets…, in reality your opponent’s play closes the door far too often. So we are more likely to see this happen when two great players go against eachother.

Looking at the results, there were only X times an individual had a chance at 8 in a row, and Y times it happened. For double perfect rounds, Y times out of Z total rounds. But the dreams are dashed even sooner for this. On average, a player misses an open 20 on just their X shot of the round, weakening the opportunity for a perfect round.
And no, Crokinole isn’t an Olympic sport. Yet.
